notes.comment:
This 2-day hands-on workshop will teach you the core concepts of object oriented programming and how to apply these concepts in real-world applications. 

This course is taught using the client's preferred language. At present, we support: C++, Java, Kotlin, Dart, JavaScript or TypeScript.

content: Limit access to fields and methods
Ex: Update math example to encapsulate internal details

notes.comment: Start coding UI against an API you wish existed

Low: GWT
High: JSF

High: XSLT
Low: SQL

content: Organization: makes it easier to find stuff

notes.comment: where to find the function to trim a string?

content: Encapsulation and abstraction: See next sections
Limit who can *read* a given field
Limit who can *mutate* a given field
Limit who can *invoke* a given method

notes.comment: Methods "for internal use only"

content: Organize: OO provides concepts and language constructs to help organize large codebases

notes.comment: finding stuff is easier

content: Complexity: These same constructs can help mange complexity in large code bases
Understand: make large code bases easier to understand
Predict: OO can help make complex programs more predictable
Reliable: OO help to make large programs more reliable
Libraries: Many libraries (built-in, 3rd party or your own) are easier to learn and use when organized around OO concepts

notes.comment: Explain how OO made learning VB easier

content: IDE: IDE's and editors potentially more helpful when consuming OO code

content: Reuse: OO provide a convenient unit of re-use

notes.comment: Decompose a large problem into smaller parts
Such that each part is:
OO does not contribute anything in the way of new and interesting end-user features (at least not directly)
OO is not a performance enhancement

content: Ex: Convert UI example from inheritance to delegation
Ex: Update math example for polymorphism

notes.comment: If you have not experienced the pain points that OO is designed to solve, it may seem hard to appreciate the value at first
We are going to introduce OO features a little bit at a time, and evolve our examples at each step
At some intermediate stages, our examples won't necessarily represent an optimal solution
Programming with an explicit sequence of commands that update global, shared, mutable state.
Imagine an app with 1000 global variables
Programming by specifying the result you want, not how to get it.
Ex: SQL
Programming with clean, goto-free, nested control structures.
Imperative programming with procedure calls.
Imagine an app with 1000 global variables and 1000 global functions.
In this model there is only one scope: global
All variables are global: any function can read any (or every) variable
All functions are global: Any function can call any other (or every other) function
Programming with function calls that avoid any global state.
Procedural and functional are polar opposites
OO Fits in the middle
OO advantage over all global
OO advantage over pure functional
https://cs.lmu.edu/~ray/notes/paradigms/
Programming languages that work like this are easy to learn

content: Con: large apps become hard to understand

notes.comment:
Imagine an app with 1000 global variables and 1000 global functions.
Since all vars are global, any function may be reading or mutating any var.
Any function can inadvertently break any other function by changing some shared global variables

content: Pro: predictable and easy to test
Pro: safe and reliable for concurrency
A function only knows what you pass it
The extra work of of passing data around can be a pain
If you 10 functions operating on the same data, you have to pass that data 10 times
Break large problem into smaller parts
Interface should be simple to use for clients
Interface should be stable over time
Implementation can change over time without breaking client code
Types of implementation change over time

notes.comment:
Performance improvements
Make code cleaner more readable
Switch technologies
Hide JavaScript

Stored procedures
Java or C functions
In this workshop we build a non-trivial project over the course of 2 days. Much of this work takes the form of "do on your own" exercises. Through this project, we learn the core concepts of OOP.
This course is taught using the client's preferred language.  Students should have a basic, but not advanced, knowledge of that programming language.
Consider the list of topics below as a starting point. We often add, remove and skim topics based on the prerequisites and preferences of the students.
